p: There was not a significant difference in cathelicidin concentrations between dogs with sepsis (mean, SD; 8.29, 0.47), critically ill without sepsis (8.90, 0.82), and healthy controls (8.52, 0.62; P = 0.32; one‐way ANOVA). There was not a significant correlation between 25(OH)D and cathelicidin expression (rs = −0.14, P = 0.55; spearman correlation). Thirty‐three percent (4/12) of critically ill dogs did not survive to discharge. Cathelicidin concentrations were not predictive of survival to discharge ( P = 0.64; logistic regression). Dogs with sepsis (mean, SD; 26.1 ng/ml, 9.2, P = 0.001), and critically ill dogs without sepsis (18.7 ng/mL, 9.4, P < 0.001) had significantly decreased serum 25(OH)D compared to healthy controls (53.9 ng/ml, 15.7, one‐way ANOVA). Severity of illness defined by APPLEfast scores ( P = 0.22), serum 25(OH)D concentration ( P = 0.25), and presence of sepsis ( P = 0.42; logistic regression) were not predictive of survival.
